comments.commentBody: Thank you. It is very disappointing that the average NYT reader cannot comprehend what s/he is reading and yet feels fully qualified to profess experise in art and politics.
Rampling was speaking in French, so it's not possible for Gay to misquote her in English.
Diversity is a ridiculous liberal attempt to solve anything.  People are free to make their own choices without social engineers deciding what the outcome has to be.

Actually, yes. A quota system was suggested.

A boycott of the awards because no Blacks were nominated was also suggested.

Some white people who are older are being targeted as racists because they disagreed with one of both of those suggestions.

I'm having a hard time caring about this. Is anyone suggesting a quota system? A certain percentage of votes must go to a certain minority? Of course not.  This is show BUSINESS. There are many deserving white actors, producers, directors and writers who have never won an Oscar. Who cares? Let's all go to the lobby and have ourselves some popcorn.

She did not "back down".

She clarified for the people who didn't understand her because their jerked knees were blocking their eyes.

So far this century, African American actors have made up a slightly larger percentage of best-actor/actress Oscar nomination than they do of the U.S. population, but it’s not surprising none were nominated this year. For example, African American males make up about 6 percent of the U.S. population, but probably less than 3 percent of actors eligible for best actor nominations. (The Oscars only go to actors in English-language films made anywhere in the world. This excludes most films made in Asia, Africa and Latin America. ) A black male nominated for best actor would take up 20 percent of best actor nominations. It’s unrealistic to expect 20 percent of best actor award nominations go to such a small segment of eligible actors every year. The same is true for actresses, directors and screenwriters.

Holllywood--one of the most Liberal places on earth--with a racism problem? I thought only Republicans and Tea Party folks were racist?

Truth be known...as much as Democrats love to talk about tolerance and inclusiveness, the most racist person on earth is an elitist Liberal, hunkered down behind high walls and iron gates, in Long Island or San Francisco. They're the ones most likely to worry that one of "those people" will come shoot them and take their stuff.
Ms. Gay spoke of women and other minorities.
I'm surprised by the racist comments here at the NYT, but not really, racism is open and rampant since President Obama came into office.  It turns my stomach.

Hatred and racism as a response to differences is ultimately alienating and separating whether expressed by Roxane Gay or Donald Trump. Most stark in this discourse as with Ta-Nehisi Coates and others is equating inherently "human experience" as exclusive to race and color identity. In my parents "conversations" between 7-10 I was warned about the dangers of the street, the building, its' elevator, the basement, child molesters and strangers, the subway, etcetera. I too was poor: parents slept in living room, shared bedroom with brother, landlord came looking for the rent. Not every injustice and failure to get what you want, to be liked, acknowledged or recognized is due to skin color or poverty. The depth of hatred, the retrograde tone toward "white" skin and privilege is both revelation and reminder. Emotionally steeped in deep hatred whatever apparently moves in your favor yet you still lose. Love, appreciation and acceptance cannot be legislated. What is the need in the cry to be nominated? Will a quota calm your heart, ease your pain? If seeking love and recognition is the game, hatred and anger are ultimately an ill conceived strategy whether you are black, brown, cream, ochre, yellow, alabaster or white, with or without privilege. Aggression and hatred veiled as true expression denigrate the viable human aspirations for inclusion and unity, ironically create more of the separation you decry. Wishing you well on your personal journey to wholeness.

Can we just get it over with and pass a law requiring that all professions, all institutions, and the distribution of prestigious awards must reflect the racial and ethnic makeup of society? Those who bemoan "underrepresentation" are often inconsistent and unprincipled, as they want select races or one gender to be at least proportionally represented, but not all or both. They want what they want for members of the tribes they favor, and that's it.

In my line of work, academia, in the absence of such a law, we routinely bend over backwards to hire female and minority graduate students with little or no teaching or publishing experience over highly accomplished white male PhD's for the few tenure track jobs that even exist any more. If the ads simply said, e.g., "no white males need apply, we already have people who look like you," at least it would be honest. We would no longer be treating people as we would never consent to be treated ourselves - being unemployed, seeing a job we'd love to have, getting our hopes up, putting great time and effort into applying for it, not knowing the whole time that we have no chance of getting it because of the race and/or gender into which we were born.

If Ms. Gay is going to insinuate that social justice demands proportional representation by race and ethnicity across the board, I look forward to her advocacy of such a law. A lot of Jews, for example, will lose their jobs, but I'm sure Ms. Gay will be fine with that.

Thank you Maureen,
I had stop reading your columns but todays title led me to read and I am grateful. There was a time when having a Sarah Palin on my arm would have boosted my poor self image and provided me the piece of jewellery that so many of my gender use to show the world they have made it. Instead I married a woman whose wisdom, compassion and knowledge make everyday a celebration of life. Even as we enter our dotage her beauty still shines through the wrinkles and I have a friend , love and companion to share the important things in life.
One of the great puzzles I am dealing with right now is why someone with all the money in the world, certainly more than average intelligence, great charm and charisma, and 10 months from claiming the most powerful office on the planet would welcome Sarah on HIS stage.

Hillary is easily the most experienced and best qualified person to be president.  Trump is the best qualified to represent the one percenter's who seek to have their taxes cut, but not yours.  Trump's goal is to pretend everything needed to get elected to a job that he is utterly unqualified to hold, and there is why we find Sarah Palin, the Queen of The Unqualified, who just had to endorse him.  Sarah and the Real estate developer do have one thing in common, they each believe themselves a legend in their own mind.

I guess it needed the unfolding of the horrid specter of the unbelievable political story to realize the greatness of President Obama. Yes, Sarah Palin is the epitome of feminism. The flint river w GM"s private toxic dumping grounds for I don't know how many years. So toxic that it ceased using it.  You're either misinformed or delibrately spewing (good word for GM on the flint river) disinformation.

We all knew the republicans were all about disenfranchising Democratic voters.
Who knew they would stoop to poisoning an entire, largely Democratic, town?

This should be a case study at your pricier B-schools of what "Running the Government Like A Business" looks like.

I grew up in Flint and the river was polluted, and toxic 50 years ago. Flint was an industrial town and the river was a dumping ground for everything. Perhaps no one in your limited circle claims the river was polluted, but people at ground zero knew better. Water chemistry, filtration and treatment is not a new science. Yet the State of Michigan in its infinite wisdom could not get it right in its haste to save a buck. The entire mess can be and should be laid at the feet of a Republican Governor and his administration who endangered the health and welfare of it's citizens. No amount of spin can deflect the responsibility for this issue.

Governor Snyder is guilty of conspiracy and negligence. He should be arrested and charged. He has poisoned 100,000 people and tries to blame bureaucrats.
Because Flint is filled with the poor and minorities, he will get away with this crime. Now if it had happened in Birmingham or Ann Arbor it would be a very, very different story.

Well, the entire nation's infrastructure is not being maintained in a systematic way.  All the monies that have been diverted or denied will at some time cause many problems that will increase cost and also have huge sums that need to be used right away.  Of course how can we  make up for years of neglect when the failures begin?  Most likely many failures will occur concurrently. If congress and the states continue to neglect and abuse the infrastructure maintenance, then I believe we will have a decade or two before many of the problems will be repaired. This is a time bomb with out a timer.  The bombs will blow due to decay.
